bibl.title: Report from J. F. Dunshie to the Chief Surgeon, August 25, 1900

div1.p: Dunshie lists the cases of yellow fever at Guanajay Barracks and reports about the precautionary methods taken to prevent the spread of the disease. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from J. F. Dunshie to the Chief Surgeon, August 25, 1900
div1.p:
I have the honor to state in connection with enclosed report
of cases of yellow fever that the following precautions were taken to
prevent the spread of the disease.

Immediately after the appearence of the first case, that of Pvt. Walker
“I” company, 1st U.S. Infty., the quarters occupied by “I” company were
cleared of all company and individual property, including box lockers bed-
ding, funniture, etc. and the floors were scrubbed with a solution of Bi-
chloride of mercury and the ceilings were white washed.

The personal property of Pvt. Walker was removed from his company
quarters to the Post Hospital where all clothing was soaked in a strong
solution of bichloride of mercury and was finally returned to his company
quarters.

Pvt. Walker was taken sick about One o'clock in the afternoon of July
4th. and did not go to his company quarters after he was taken ill, nor was
he in any of the buildings of the Post Hospital during his illness.

About July 8th a request for a Bichloride of mercury pump was made
to the Chief Surgeon of the Dept of Havana and Pinar del Rio and upon its
arrival, about July 21st, it was put into immediate use.

The barracks occupied by “I” company, 1st U.S. Infty. were again cleared
of all property and was sprayed with a solution of bichlerido of mercury
one to five hundred (1 to 500) The wards of the Hospital and the quart
ers occupied by these men of the Hospital Corps who had developed the
disease were also sprayed with large quantities of bichloride solution
one to five hundred (1 to 500) and the bed clothes, mosquito bars and the men
clothing were placed in tubs and barrels containing a strong bichloride
solution. As the men developed temperature they were removed
from the hospital and placed in tents some distance from the hospital and
as far from the other buildings as practicable.

The Hospital wards were finally cleared of all patients on July 24th,
those that could be safely returned to quarters were placed in tents in
front of and some distance from the hospital and kept there under obser-
vation some days before they were returned to their respective company
quarters.

Patients who were being treated for other than febrile diseases were
placed in tents in the same place. The hospital office was also
moved to one of the tents and these members of the Hospital Corps whose
duties did not cause their coming into contact with the fever patients
were quartered along the same line of tents.

The hospital wards and quarters previously refered to and all other
portions of the Hospital proper, including kitchen and Corps squad room
were sprayed with large quantities of bichloride of mercury solution one
to five hundred (1 to 500).

The Hospital was quarentined against the Post and the Post was quar-
entined against the town of Guanajay on the afternoon of July 22nd.

During the time that non-febrile patients were in quarters near the
Hospital all communication with the hospital was practically cut off.

About July 28th. Act. Hosp. Steward Claude M Cook who occupied one of
the tents previously refered to complained of being ill and was isolated.
also Pvt. John E Courtney, Hosp. Corps and Pvt. Harry Vancew Company “M” 1st
U.S. Infty. who occupied tents on this part of the field were isolated as
soon as they developed temperature.

On July the Office was moved to the opposite end of the post; the
kitchen and kitchen store room were also moved to the opposite end of
the post.

On July the row of tents above refered to was knocked down and
burned to prevent furthur spread of the disease and all propeerty contain
in said tents was disinfected.

Since date of last case recorded above there has been no new case
of the disease at this Post.
div1.closer:
Very Respectfully J F Dunshie Act Asst Surgeon U.S. Army
Surgeon
